{{For|other 2010 blizzards in North America|List of North American blizzards of 2010}} {{Infobox winter storm |name=December 2010 North American blizzard |image location=December 2010 Nor'easter on December 27, 2010.jpg |image name=Visible satellite imagery of the [[nor'easter]] offshore [[Cape Cod]] at peak intensity, on the morning of December 27 |date formed=December 5, 2010 |date dissipated=January 15, 2011 |RSI=3.27 |maximum amount={{convert|36|in|cm|sp=us}} at [[Brick, New Jersey]]{{cite web|url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/okx/StormEvents/storm12262010.html|accessdate=October 8, 2011|title=National Weather Service New York, NY Public Information Statement|work=[[National Weather Service]]|date=December 28, 2010}} |stormtype=[[Aleutian Low]]
[[Extratropical cyclone]]
[[Blizzard]]
[[Nor'easter]]
[[European Windstorm]] |pressure= {{convert|960|mb|inHg}}http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=12/27/2010&selmap=2010122721&maptype=satsfcnps{{cite web |url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm20/stormsum_11.html |accessdate=December 29, 2010 |title=Storm Summary Number 11 for Eastern U.S. Winter Storm |work=[[National Weather Service]] |date=December 27, 2010}} |total damages (USD)=$60 million (2010 USD){{citation needed|date=December 2010}} |total fatalities=At least 7 {{citation needed|date=December 2010}} |areas affected=[[Alaska]], [[Western Canada]], [[Contiguous United States]], [[Eastern Canada]], [[Bermuda]], [[Azores]], [[Northern Europe]], [[Russia]] |notes=Part of the '''[[Global storm activity of 2010|2010–11 North American winter]]''' }} The '''December 2010 North American blizzard''' was a major [[nor'easter]]{{cite news | url = http://voices.washingtonpost.com/capitalweathergang/2010/12/blizzard_bypasses_dc_blasts_co.html | title = Blizzard blasts coastal cities from Va. to Mass. | author = Andrew Freedman |work=The Washington Post | date = December 27, 2010 }} and historic [[blizzard]] affecting the [[Contiguous United States]] and portions of [[Canada]] from December 5–29, 2010. From January 4–15, the system was known as ''Windstorm Benjamin'' in Europe. It was the first significant winter storm of the 2010–11 North American winter storm season and the fifth [[List of North American blizzards of 2010|North American blizzard of 2010]]. The storm system affected the [[northeast megalopolis]], which includes major cities such as [[Norfolk, Virginia|Norfolk]], [[Philadelphia]], [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]], [[New York City]], [[Hartford, Connecticut|Hartford]], [[Providence, Rhode Island|Providence]], and [[Boston]]. The storm brought between {{convert|12|and|32|in|cm}} of snow in many of these areas. ==Meteorological history== {{original research|date=October 2017|section}} [[File:Atmospheric River GOES WV 20101220.1200.goes11.vapor.x.pacus.x.jpg|thumb|left|The storm system (situated off the coast of [[Washington (state)|Washington]] at the time of this image) battering the [[Western United States]], on December 21.]] On December 5, 2010, an extratropical disturbance developed in the western [[Gulf of Alaska]], along a [[stationary front]].http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=12/05/2010&selmap=2010120506&maptype=satsfcnps During the next few days, the system rapidly intensified, while channeling smaller winter storms and moisture from the [[Pineapple Express]] [[atmospheric river]] in the west coast of North America, before approaching the North American west coast itself on December 8.http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=12/08/2010&selmap=2010120800&maptype=satsfcnps On December 9, a new low pressure area formed to the south of [[Alaska]] in the storm system's circulation,http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=12/09/2010&selmap=2010120912&maptype=satsfcnps becoming the dominant low of the storm on December 11, when the original low pressure center dissipated over the coast of [[British Columbia]].http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=12/11/2010&selmap=2010121109&maptype=satsfcnps During the next few days, the storm system slowly looped back westward while slowly strengthening,http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=12/12/2010&selmap=2010121200&maptype=satsfcnps before moving back towards the West Coast on December 13.http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=12/13/2010&selmap=2010121303&maptype=satsfcnps During this time, the storm system channeled more moisture into the Pacific Northwest and other neighboring regions, triggering flooding in some areas. After stalling for a day, on December 14, the central circulation split again, with the original center of circulation intensifying and moving ashore,http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=12/14/2010&selmap=2010121412&maptype=satsfcnps while the new low stalled in the northern Gulf of Alaska became the dominant low of the storm.http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=12/15/2010&selmap=2010121506&maptype=satsfcnps On December 15, the Aleutian Low opened up a large [[atmospheric river]] (the [[Pineapple Express]]) again, over California, which fed the storm system moisture, allowing it to strengthen significantly. This in turn brought torrents of rain and occasional gusts of wind, while the main storm itself slowly strengthened while stalling in the Gulf of Alaska.http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=12/15/2010&selmap=2010121512&maptype=satsfcnps By December 15, a powerful [[Kona low]] (which would later become [[Tropical Storm Omeka]]) had also set up near [[Hawaii]], feeding additional moisture into the Pineapple Express, which in turn strengthened the storm system even further. The favorable weather pattern allowed the storm to retain its intensity, even while it slowly moved down towards the West Coast. The massive storm complex slowly looped westward and then southward towards the West Coast, undergoing explosive intensification once more on December 19.http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=12/19/2010&selmap=2010121900&maptype=satsfcnps The system stalled off the coast of the Pacific Northwest, and weakened slightly. However, the system fully opened up the Pineapple Express over California beginning on December 19,http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=12/19/2010&selmap=2010121918&maptype=satsfcnps triggering flash floods, mudslides, and landslides across much of the Western States, particularly in California. The Pineapple Express system channeled large amounts of moisture into California, ravaging much of the state from December 15 through December 22, bringing with it as much as 20 inches of rain to the San Gabriel Mountains and San bernardinos and over 13 feet of snow in the Southern California mountains and [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]]. Although the entire state was affected, the Southern California counties of San Bernardino, Orange, San Diego, and Los Angeles bore the brunt of the system of storms as coastal and hillside areas were impacted by mudslides and major flooding.{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2010/12/22/S-Calif-storm-unleashes-torrent-of-rain/UPI-41611293008400/ |title=Pineapple Express blamed for S. Cal storms |publisher=UPI.com |date=December 22, 2010 |accessdate=March 19, 2012}} During the time that the storm stalled off the West Coast, the system brought significant rain, snow, and mudslides California the Southwest region. On December 21, the storm complex's central circulation fell apart, as it began to interact with another storm in the Gulf of Alaska.http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=12/22/2010&selmap=2010122200&maptype=satsfcnps On December 22, after stalling off the West Coast for 5 days, the weakened system finally approached [[Southern California]] and began moving ashore,http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=12/22/2010&selmap=2010122212&maptype=satsfcnps making landfall early on December 23, which finally put a temporary end to the Pineapple Express event.http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=12/23/2010&selmap=2010122300&maptype=satsfcnps Later the same day, the winter storm weakened into a small, 1011 mbar storm, after moving eastward into the [[Four Corners|Four Corners region]].http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=12/23/2010&selmap=2010122315&maptype=satsfcnps On December 23, the winter storm interacted with another frontal system, causing the storm to weaken even further, to the point where the storm lost its circulation.http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=12/24/2010&selmap=2010122400&maptype=satsfcnps By the time the winter storm reached southern [[Texas]] later in December 2010, almost all of the system's convection had dissipated.http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=12/24/2010&selmap=2010122409&maptype=satsfcnps [[File:Dec10noreaster.png|thumb|right|250px|Infrared satellite image of the storm on Monday, December 27, 2010]] Late on December 24, the winter storm began absorbing an ample amount of Gulf stream energy; as a result, the storm was able to reorganize.http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=12/24/2010&selmap=2010122421&maptype=satsfcnps The core of the storm eventually moved southeast into the [[Gulf of Mexico]] then abruptly turned sharply northeastward into the Florida panhandle and state of Georgia as it merged with an upper-level low pressure system located near Virginia. As it became a stacked low pressure system, the storm system began a period of [[rapid intensification]] off the North Carolina coast while tracking along the coast of the Northeast and Newfoundland. The storm had many similarities to [[North American blizzard of 2006]]. The storm also generated a rare meteorological phenomenon known as [[thundersnow]] in which thunder and lightning occur concurrently with the falling snow. On December 27, 2010, the storm had deepened to {{convert|960|mbar|inHg}}, equal in pressure to that found in a [[Category 3 hurricane]]. Several [[Synoptic scale meteorology|synoptic factors]] contributed to the intensity of this blizzard.[http://www.erh.noaa.gov/okx/SOO/case_studies/12262010.html "December 26-27th 2010 Blizzard"], National Weather Service, New York City The global American and European weather models encountered exceptional difficulty in portraying the path of the storm. The main issue that the models were trying to resolve was whether or not the upper-level low pressure system from Central Canada was going to phase in time with the southern stream energy, thereby revealing if the resulting storm would come up the Eastern Seaboard or simply continue to move east out to sea in the Atlantic Ocean. The latter solution would have only caused the storm to affect the Mid-Atlantic states of Virginia and North Carolina with a modest winter storm instead of the entire Eastern coastline up to Atlantic Canada. As such, it was only 24 hours prior to the storm's arrival in the Northeastern states when all the European and American models were in agreement that the storm would turn up the entire coastline. The National Weather Service's [[Hydrometeorological Prediction Center]] and many other private forecasters were skeptical of the storm impacting the Northeastern states until about 24 hours of the storm's arrival as well; although, some models depicted the storm delivering a full-blown blizzard to the New York City metropolitan area as early as a week in advance. The Hydrometeorological Prediction Center even issued a statement on Christmas Eve, 48 hours prior to the storm, that they suspected the American models of having model initialization errors; thus, they believed these errors may have forced the storm to be erroneously modeled to come up the Northeastern coast.[http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/event_reviews/2010/December25_27_2010_Blizzard.pdf "HPC's Case Study of the December 25–27 Northeast Blizzard"] On December 27, the storm developed into a powerful [[nor'easter]] that buffeted the East Coast, reaching its peak intensity. On December 29, the storm weakened and left the United States. During the next several days, the system moved eastward over the Atlantic Ocean. On January 2, 2011, the storm began to re-intensify, but the system continued to drift in the eastern North Atlantic for another two days. On January 4, the system was named ''Windstorm Benjamin'' by the [[Free University of Berlin]],http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Analyse_20110104.gif which names all Low and High-Pressure systems that affect Europe. Windstorm Benjamin continued to moved eastwards across the Atlantic, and the storm began to impact [[Western Europe]] on January 8.http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Analyse_20110108.gif On January 9, Windstorm Benjamin crossed the [[British Isles]] and turned to the northeast.http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Analyse_20110109.gif For the next couple of days, Windstorm Benjamin held its intensity as it continued moving northeastward, before weakening on January 11, due to land interaction with the northern coast of [[Norway]]. On January 12, Windstorm Benjamin began to move inland into [[Central Russia|Western Russia]], while slowly weakening.http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Analyse_20110112.gif On January 13, Benjamin accelerated eastward, while rapidly continuing to deteriortate. On January 15, Windstorm Benjamin was absorbed into the circulation of another approaching extratropical cyclone.http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Analyse_20110115.gif ==Synoptic conditions== ===Snowfall=== [[WCAU-TV]] in [[Philadelphia]] forecast a snowfall of between {{convert|10|and|20|in|cm}} in Philadelphia itself (which received {{convert|12.2|in|cm}}), while nearby [[Trenton, New Jersey]] and parts of southern [[New Jersey]] were expected to receive snowfalls of {{convert|20|in|cm}} or more. Wind gusts were expected to reach between {{convert|40|and|50|mph|km/h}}.[http://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/breaking/Major-Snowstorm-Sunday-After-Christmas-112452614.html "Heavy Snow Slams Region"]. Retrieved December 26, 2010. Areas in eastern [[North Carolina]] and southeastern [[Virginia]] saw upwards of {{convert|12|in|cm}} of snow. [[File:DeLury Sq Fulton Gold jeh.jpg|thumb|left|Manhattan as snowfall begins]] [[File:Madison Square 2010 blizzard.jpg|thumb|left|Broadway at end of snowfall]] Areas in and around New York City, which were most impacted by the storm, reported between {{convert|12|and|32|in|cm}} of snowfall by Monday morning. Measurement was made difficult due to {{convert|4|ft|cm|adj=on}} snow drifts caused by the winds. Central Park's reported {{convert|20|in|cm}} of snow from the storm is the sixth-largest snowfall on record for that location. Areas to the east of New York City received 10 to 20 inches while 20 to 30 inches of snow fell across New York City, Northeast and Central New Jersey and the Lower Hudson Valley. Areas receiving the most snow are between [[Kendall Park, New Jersey|Kendall Park]] and [[Elizabeth, New Jersey|Elizabeth]] and between [[Brick, New Jersey|Brick]] and [[Atlantic City, New Jersey|Atlantic City]] in [[New Jersey]]. This was because multiple convective bands of heavy snow fed in off the ocean into the large stationary very heavy snow band (with occasional lightning) over the areas that received 20 to 30 inches. These areas received snowfall totals over {{convert|24.0|in|cm|sp=us}}. A secondary heavy snow/rain band formed across Eastern Massachusetts the night of December 26. Southern [[New England]] including Boston saw more than {{convert|1|ft|cm}} of snow. Even areas of coastal Virginia saw more than {{convert|1|ft|cm}} of snow, and [[North Carolina]] received more than {{convert|6.0|in|cm|sp=us}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/nfdscc1.html|accessdate=December 28, 2010|title=National Weather Service Hydrometeorological Prediction Center Storm Summary Message|work=[[National Weather Service]]|date=December 28, 2010}} Washington, D.C. and [[Baltimore]] and their environs were largely spared this storm, receiving little accumulation despite large snowfall totals further east on the [[Delmarva Peninsula]]. ===High winds=== Wind gusts routinely over {{convert|50|mph|sp=us}} were widespread during the blizzard in coastal areas. Hurricane-force wind gusts of {{convert|80|mph|sp=us}} were recorded along coastal portions of Eastern [[Massachusetts]]. A wind gust of {{convert|94.4|mph|sp=us}} was recorded in Grand Etang, Nova Scotia.[http://www.wunderground.com/history/airport/CWZQ/2010/12/27/DailyHistory.html?req_city=NA&req_state=NA&req_statename=NA Weather station history for CWZQ, Grand Etang, NS] The Greater New York area had sustained winds of 30–45 MPH with gusts to over 60 MPH during the afternoon and night of December 26. High winds caused near zero visibilities and treacherous travel conditions in many areas. The strong easterly winds also piled up water along the eastern coast of Massachusetts, leading to major coastal flood damage. ==Impact== Late on December 25, [[WPVI-TV]] announced that the [[National Weather Service]] had issued blizzard warnings for northern and parts of central New Jersey, New York City, [[Long Island]] and coastal southern [[New England]].[http://abclocal.go.com/wpvi/gallery?section=weather&id=7863979&photo=1 WPVI-TV map showing counties affected by blizzard warning]. Retrieved 2010-12-26.{{verify source|date=December 2010}} [[WABC-TV]] also offered information on the blizzard warning that was posted throughout the New York City region.[http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=weather/forecast&id=6563415 WABC-TV page referencing blizzard warnings in NYC area] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101212112320/http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=weather%2Fforecast&id=6563415 |date=December 12, 2010 }}. Retrieved 2010-12-26.{{verify source|date=December 2010}} On December 26, several closures were announced on [[KYW (AM)|KYW-1060]] (the all-news radio station in [[Philadelphia]]), including the [[Please Touch Museum]] and [[Independence National Historical Park]].[http://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2010/12/26/community-cancellations-sunday-december-26th/ CBS Philadelphia page with closings]. Retrieved 2010-12-26.{{dead link|date=December 2010}} Philadelphia mayor [[Michael Nutter]] declared a [[snow emergency]] beginning at 2:00 p.m. local time.[http://www.delawareonline.com/article/20101226/NEWS/101226004/Nutter+sets+2+p.m.+snow+emergency+in+Philly+ "Nutter sets 2 p.m. snow emergency in Philly"]. Delaware Online. Retrieved December 26, 2010. The [[National Football League|NFL]] game between the [[Minnesota Vikings]] and the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] at [[Lincoln Financial Field]] in Philadelphia, scheduled for Sunday, December 26, was postponed until Tuesday, December 28.[http://www.philadelphiaeagles.com/index2.html Philadelphia Eagles home page]. Retrieved 2010-12-26.{{verify source|date=December 2010}} Ironically, it was scheduled to be played Sunday afternoon, but flexed to the primetime slot, displacing the [[San Diego Chargers]]-[[Cincinnati Bengals]] game to the afternoon. Boston declared a State of Emergency Sunday afternoon with an expected accumulation of over {{convert|20|in|cm}}.[http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2010/12/26/patrick_declares_state_of_emergency_in_mass/ Patrick declares state of emergency in Mass.]. Associated Press. ''The Boston Globe''. December 26, 2010. Delaware had declared a State of Emergency on Sunday evening.{{cite news | url=http://www.doverpost.com/features/x1682036058/Gov-Markell-declares-limited-state-of-emergency | title=Gov. Markell declares limited state of emergency | accessdate=December 28, 2010 | date=December 26, 2010 | work=Dover Post}} [[Amtrak]]'s ''[[Acela Express]]'' and regular ''[[Northeast Regional]]'' service was shut down completely between Boston and New York.[http://www.boston.com/news/local/breaking_news/2010/12/amtrak_shutting.html At South Station, passengers grapple with surprise shutdown by Amtrak] ===North Carolina=== North Carolina was one of six US states where a [[state of emergency]] was declared due to the storm.{{cite news|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/2010/12/26/882319/mid-atlantic-northeast-brace-for.html#storylink=misearch|title=East Coast storm strands travelers, vexes drivers|last=Tucker|first=Eric|work=[[News & Observer]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=December 26, 2010|accessdate=December 29, 2010}} Snow totals in the state ranged from less than {{convert|1|to|10|in|cm}} in the east, from {{convert|5|to|12|in|cm}} in the central part of the state and along the I-95 corridor, and from {{convert|3|to|15|in|cm}} in the west.{{cite news|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/2010/12/26/882363/overnight-snow-blankets-triangle.html#storylink=misearch|title=Snow tapers off, but morning commute will be dicey|work=[[News & Observer]]|date=December 26, 2010|accessdate=December 29, 2010}} [[File:Subway-closed.jpg|thumb|right|No trains running on the [[BMT Brighton Line]] as the result of the storm.]] [[File:Herald Sq entry arch snow jeh.jpg|thumb|[[Herald Square]]]] [[File:Milk crate stepping stone W43 puddle jeh.theora.ogv|thumb|right|New Yorkers cross a deep melt puddle (half minute video)]] ===New York City=== By the storm's end, weather stations in [[Central Park]] had recorded {{convert|20|in|cm}} of snow. A combination of heavy snow and strong winds led to massive transportation lockdowns across the city. Nearly all roads in the city (with the exception of major arteries) were left impassable for many days because of the amount of snow. Hundreds of buses were stuck in the snow.[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/30/nyregion/30response.html NYTimes, Dec 29, 2010] Hundreds of buses stranded More than 400 passengers were stranded on the [[A (New York City Subway service)|A train]] on the [[IND Rockaway Line]] for seven hours starting shortly before 1 a.m.{{cite news | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203731004576046082386121562 | date = December 27, 2010 | title = Snow Keeps City at Standstill | author = Andrew Grossman |work=The Wall Street Journal | accessdate =December 28, 2010 }} One train did not open its doors when it stopped at the station. Dozens of [[Long Island Rail Road|LIRR]] trains were frozen onto the platforms. Hundreds of plows were on the road. NYC's [[List of airports in the New York City area|major airports]], [[John F. Kennedy International Airport|Kennedy]], [[Newark Liberty International Airport|Newark]] and [[LaGuardia Airport|LaGuardia]] were shut down until 6:00 p.m. Monday evening.{{cite news | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203513204576047251243335300 | date = December 28, 2010 | title = Blizzard Strands Travelers Across U.S. | author = Susan Carey |work=The Wall Street Journal | accessdate =December 28, 2010 }} The MTA ran on a limited schedule, even on Tuesday morning, with many above ground subway lines not functioning. By Wednesday, only the [[BMT Sea Beach Line|Sea Beach Line]], [[BMT Franklin Avenue Line|Franklin Avenue Line]], and [[Greenport Branch]] remained suspended. The subway resumed full service on Thursday, the LIRR Friday morning. Residents of the city were complaining to Mayor [[Michael Bloomberg]] about the slowness of the snowplows attempting to reach their areas. By the late afternoon on Tuesday, snowplows had reached the minor streets in [[Brooklyn]]. Many residents of [[Staten Island]], however, had yet to see one. Many plows became stuck in the snow that had accumulated on the streets and several could not get through as many residents had simply abandoned their cars in the middle of roads once it became too hazardous or impossible to move. These cars became stuck as the snow accumulated around them, creating roadblocks for the plows. Both Mayor Bloomberg and the chief of the sanitation department were urging residents to stay indoors and not shovel snow back onto the streets that had already been plowed. State Senator [[Carl Kruger]] called the response a "Colossal Failure".[http://www.myfoxny.com/dpp/weather/Slow-Cleanup-From-Blizzard-2010-20101228-APX "Slow Cleanup From Blizzard 2010"] Multiple explanations have been proposed for the relatively slow response of the snow cleanup in the New York City metropolitan area. For example, the local media did not fully alert the general public until Christmas Day about the impending storm due to the complexity and lateness of the forecast models predicting the storm; thus, public awareness was delayed. Another possible cause was that Mayor Bloomberg had previously laid off 400 New York City Sanitation workers due to budget cuts; therefore, fewer plows were at work. In addition, some city workers who are responsible for managing the snow removal process had taken the day off from work during the storm due to the Christmas holiday. Also, a [[snow emergency]] was not declared, contributing to the number of abandoned cars on the streets. On December 30, the New York Post reported that several sanitation workers confessed that cleanup was intentionally slowed down to protest the aforementioned budget cuts.{{cite web|last=Goldenberg|first=Sally|title=Sanitation Department's slow snow cleanup was a budget protest|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/sanit_filthy_snow_slow_mo_qH57MZwC53QKOJlekSSDJK|work=New York Post|accessdate=December 30, 2010|author2=Celona, Larry |author3=Margolin, Josh }} On January 3, 2011, [[WCBS-TV]] reported that prosecutors had obtained a video of two sanitation trucks driving down 155th Street in [[Whitestone, Queens]] after the blizzard with their plows raised so as not to remove the snow. Allegations were also made that sanitation workers slept on the job, hung out at a doughnut shop for 11 straight hours while on the job, and drank beer for six or seven hours while on the job. Claims were also made that supervisors encouraged such work stoppages.[http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2011/01/03/video-of-apparent-blizzard-clean-up-slow-down-surfaces/ Video Of Apparent Blizzard Clean-Up, Slow-Down Surfaces], WCBS-TV, January 3, 2011 However, a month later, the [[New York Times]] reported that the allegations of a slowdown remained unsubstantiated and that Councilman Daniel Halloran, who had originally reported the confessions, had not named his sources.[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/26/nyregion/26snowman.html?_r=1&src=me&ref=nyregion Evidence Is Elusive on Charge of a Blizzard Slowdown], New York Times, January 25, 2011 A man who attempted suicide by jumping from a ninth-story window was saved when he landed on a huge pile of garbage that had accumulated during the blizzard.[http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/manhattan/garbage_breaks_suicide_jumper_fall_Cpt0tOWKjjAChfu5GVkWoL Garbage breaks suicide jumper's fall], New York Post, January 2, 2011 Two casualties were reported as the result of emergency workers being unable to reach those in need: a newborn baby and an elderly woman.[http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/12/29/2010-12-29_help_arrives_too_late_to_save_baby.html Death of newborn baby among several blizzard tragedies as city is accused of 'dropping the ball'] === New Jersey === [[File:Snow in Journal Square 27 December 2010.jpg|Left|thumb|Snowing in [[Journal Square]], [[Jersey City, New Jersey]]]] [[New Jersey]] declared a State of Emergency on Sunday, December 26.[http://www.app.com/article/20101226/NEWS/12260364/State-of-emergency-declared-in-NJ Shore gets buried by blizzard, state of emergency declared] APP.com December 26, 2010 They were affected the hardest because of its high winds and snow. Over {{convert|20|in|cm}} of snow was estimated in some counties such as [[Union County, New Jersey|Union County]]. [[Interstate 78]], [[Interstate 80]], and [[Interstate 280 (New Jersey)|Interstate 280]] experienced congestion, closures, and accidents. [[New Jersey Transit]] suspended all bus service, [[North Jersey Coast Line]] service, and [[Hudson-Bergen Light Rail]] Service. [[River Line (New Jersey Transit)|River Line]] service had partial closures and the [[Newark Light Rail]] was delayed for 20–30 minutes.[http://www.njtransit.com/sa/sa_servlet.srv?hdnPageAction=[[Rahway, New Jersey]]TravelAlertsTo&rel=Bus Travel Alerts] New Jersey Transit Many people in the state were stranded on roadways and only emergency vehicles were allowed on the roads. The highest amount recorded was in [[Brick, New Jersey]], where 36 inches of snow accumulated. The visibility was near {{convert|0|miles}}. Central and Northeastern New Jersey were hit the hardest with snow totals of {{convert|1|to|2.5|ft|cm}}. [[Edison, New Jersey|Edison]] got {{convert|32.5|in|cm|sp=us}}, [[Lyndhurst, New Jersey|Lyndhurst]] got {{convert|29|in|cm|sp=us}}[http://www.northjersey.com/news/122710_Blizzard_expected_to_set_North_Jersey_snowfall_records_for_Dec_27.html "Update: Lots of snow, but no records, meteorologist says"] and [[Elizabeth, New Jersey|Elizabeth]] had one of the highest totals of snow of any city affected by this storm, {{convert|31.8|in|cm|sp=us}} of heavy snow. Blizzard Warnings were prompted for eastern New Jersey, while Winter Storm Warnings were issued in the western portion. Blowing and drifting snow was a big problem on December 26 and 27. [[Newark Liberty International Airport]] in [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]] had received {{convert|7|in|cm}} of snowfall in about three hours, an instance of very heavy snow in a short time. Snow drifts as high as seven feet were spotted in portions of eastern New Jersey. The NJ Transit was shut down on late December 26 due to blizzard conditions occurring in the area. [[Cape May, New Jersey|Cape May]] was one of many southern New Jersey towns that were affected by snow bands containing four-inch per hour snowfall rates. When the storm was off the coast of New Jersey, bands of heavy snow formed one after another, increasing already-hefty snowfall amounts even further. There were reports of snow plows getting stuck in the snow late at night on December 26 and the early morning of the 27th. On the 26th, visibilities in some towns were less than 0.1 miles. This caused [[Whiteout (weather)|whiteout]] conditions in towns along the [[Raritan River]] and the Atlantic coastline. Cape May had reported nearly 15 inches of snow after the storm had moved out to sea. The town had lesser snow amounts due to a break in the southern half of the snow bands pivoting toward New Jersey. The snow totals were only expected to reach 10 to 15 inches at the highest. Instead, the highest amount was in [[Brick, New Jersey]] where 36 inches fell, nearly 3 feet of snow fell. I-95 Northbound was mostly covered in layers of snow, which was dangerous for some drivers. The higher snowfall amounts occurred in central and northern coastal areas of New Jersey. The blustery winds in New Jersey gusted as high as 65 mph. The fact of the high winds caused the blizzard warnings to be issued by the [[Mount Holly, New Jersey]] ([[Philadelphia, PA]] area) National Weather Service officials. Snow fell so fast that traffic came to a complete halt. Motorists had to be rescued the following day as snow continued to pile up and trap them on interstates and local streets, which themselves became completely impassable. Citizens began calling into news stations asking for help and giving reports, while plows and other emergency personnel became stuck everywhere. [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]] Mayor [[Cory Booker]] notably used Twitter to help stranded residents and assure citizens. ===Connecticut=== Heavy snow and winds of up to {{convert|60|mph|km/h}} caused a gas station roof to collapse in [[North Haven, Connecticut|North Haven]], and widespread tree damage and power outages throughout the state. Service on the [[Metro-North]] New Haven Line and its branches was suspended on Monday due to equipment and switch failures caused by the storm.[http://www.wtnh.com/dpp/weather/winter_weather/blizzard-connecticut-dec-27-2010 Blizzard Warnings Remain in Effect, Thousands Without Power, WTNH-TV New Haven, CT, December 27, 2010]{{cite news| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/28/nyregion/28blizzard.html| date = December 26, 2010| title = After Blizzard Ends, a Slow Recovery| author = Liz Robbins|work=The New York Times| accessdate =December 28, 2010}} The greatest snow totals were in the western part of the state, with [[Wilton, Connecticut|Wilton]] receiving 18 inches of snow. [[North Canaan, Connecticut|North Canaan]] reported 16.1 inches, and 13.9 inches of snowfall was reported at [[Bradley International Airport]]. The blizzard was nicknamed Winter Storm "Adrienne" by [[WFSB-TV]] Channel 3. The local CBS affiliate has unofficially [https://web.archive.org/web/20100213002000/http://www.wfsb.com/stormnames/index.html named local winter storms] since 1971. ===Maine=== Blizzard conditions arrived in Maine on December 27. On December 28, a [[ski lift]] at the [[Sugarloaf (ski resort)|Sugarloaf]] ski resort derailed, causing several skiers to receive injuries after falling to the ground, sending seven to the hospital.{{cite news|last=Paulson|first=Amanda|title=Sugarloaf Mountain: How common are serious ski lift accidents?|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/2010/1228/Sugarloaf-Mountain-How-common-are-serious-ski-lift-accidents|accessdate=December 28, 2010|newspaper=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |date=December 28, 2010}}{{cite news|last=Kamlet|first=Lee|title=Skiers Plummet When Maine Ski Lift Derails|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/skiers-trapped-injured-sugarloaf-mountain-ski-lift-derailment/story?id=12492517|accessdate=December 28, 2010|newspaper=ABC News|date=December 28, 2010}}{{cite news|title=Southside Va. treated to a white Christmas|url=http://www.vancnews.com/articles/2010/12/28/south_hill/news/news41.txt|accessdate=December 28, 2010|newspaper=Smith Hill Enterprise|date=December 28, 2010}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ===Massachusetts=== Coastal Massachusetts, along with coastal Maine, bore the brunt of the storm with a recorded wind gust of {{convert|153|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} in [[Scituate, Massachusetts]]. ===Atlantic Canada=== In [[Atlantic Canada]], the nor'easter was the fourth major [[winter storm]] to hit the area in four weeks. Blizzard conditions forced numerous road closures and resulted in the death of a minivan driver on December 27 near [[Fredericton, Prince Edward Island]]. {{Citations broken|date=November 2015}} [[file:Diazenylium.png|frameless|right]] '''Diazenylium''' is the chemical N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup>, an [[inorganic]] [[cation]] that was one of the first [[ion]]s to be observed in [[interstellar clouds]]. Since then, it has been observed for in several different types of [[interstellar medium|interstellar environments]], observations that have several different scientific uses. It gives astronomers information about the fractional [[ionization]] of gas clouds, the chemistry that happens within those clouds, and it is often used as a tracer for molecules that are not as easily detected (such as [[Nitrogen|N<sub>2</sub>]]).<ref>[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1995ApJ...455L..77C P. Caselli, P.C. Myers, and P. Thaddeus, ApJL, 455: L77 (1995)]</ref> Its 1–0 rotational transition occurs at 93.174 GHz, a region of the spectrum where [[Earth's atmosphere]] is transparent<ref>[http://www.submm.caltech.edu/cso/weather/atplot.shtml CSO Atmospheric Transmission Interactive Plotter]</ref> and it has a significant [[optical depth]] in both cold and warm clouds<ref>[http://www.aanda.org/index.php?option=article&access=standard&Itemid=129&url=/articles/aa/abs/2003/26/aa3576/aa3576.html L. Pirogov, I. Zinchenko, P. Caselli, L.E.B. Johansson and P. C. Myers, A&A, 405: 639-654 (2003)]</ref> so it is relatively easy to observe with ground-based observatories. The results of N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> observations can be used not only for determining the chemistry of interstellar clouds, but also for mapping the density and velocity profiles of these clouds.<ref>{{cite journal |title = Dense Cores in Dark Clouds. XIV. N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> (1–0) Maps of Dense Cloud Cores |last1 = Caselli |first1 = Paola |last2 = Benson |first2 = Priscilla J. |last3 = Myers |first3 = Philip C. |last4 = Tafalla |first4 = Mario |journal = [[The Astrophysical Journal]] |issn = 0004-637X |volume = 572 |issue = 1 |year = 2002 |pages = 238–63 |doi = 10.1086/340195 |arxiv = astro-ph/0202173 |bibcode = 2002ApJ...572..238C }}</ref>
== Astronomical detections == N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> was first observed in 1974 by B.E. Turner. He observed a previously unidentified triplet at 93.174 GHz using the NRAO 11 m telescope.<ref>[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-bib_query?bibcode=1974ApJ...193L..83T B. Turner, ApJ, 193: L83 (1974)]</ref> Immediately after this initial observation, Green et al. identified the triplet as the 1–0 rotational transition of N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup>. This was done using a combination of [[Ab initio quantum chemistry methods|ab initio molecular calculations]] and comparison of similar molecules, such as [[nitrogen|N<sub>2</sub>]], [[carbon monoxide|CO]], [[hydrogen cyanide|HCN]], [[hydrogen isocyanide|HNC]], and HCO<sup>+</sup>, which are all [[isoelectronic]] to N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup>. Based on these calculations, the observed rotational transition would be expected to have seven hyperfine components, but only three of these were observed, since the telescope's resolution was insufficient to distinguish the peaks caused by the hyperfine splitting of the inner Nitrogen atom.<ref>[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-bib_query?bibcode=1974ApJ...193L..89G S. Green, J. Montgomery, and P. Thaddeus, ApJ, 193: L89 (1974)]</ref> Just a year later, Thaddeus and Turner observed the same transition in the [[Orion Molecular Cloud Complex|Orion Molecular Cloud 2]] (OMC-2) using the same telescope, but this time they integrated for 26 hours, which resulted in a resolution that was good enough to distinguish the smaller hyperfine components.<ref>[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1975ApJ...201L..25T P. Thaddeus and B.E. Turner, ApJ, 201: L25-L26 (1975)]</ref>
Over the past three decades, N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> has been observed quite frequently, and the 1–0 rotational band is almost exclusively the one that astronomers look for. In 1995, the hyperfine structure of this septuplet was observed with an absolute precision of ~7 kHz, which was good enough to determine its molecular constants with an order of magnitude better precision than was possible in the laboratory.<ref>[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1995ApJ...455L..77C P. Caselli, P. Myers, and P. Thaddeus, ApJL, 455: L77 (1995)]</ref> This observation was done toward L1512 using the 37 m NEROC Haystack Telescope. In the same year, Sage et al. observed the 1–0 transition of N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> in seven out of the nine nearby galaxies that they observed with the NRAO 12 m telescope at Kitt Peak.<ref>[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1995ApJ...447..625S L. Sage and L. Ziurys, ApJ, 447: 625 (1995)]</ref> N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> was one of the first few molecular ions to be observed in other galaxies, and its observation helped to show that the chemistry in other galaxies is quite similar to that which we see in our own galaxy.
N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> is most often observed in dense molecular clouds, where it has proven useful as one of the last molecules to freeze out onto dust grains as the density of the cloud increases toward the center. In 2002, Bergin et al. did a spatial survey of dense cores to see just how far toward the center N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> could be observed and found that its abundance drops by at least two orders of magnitude when one moves from the outer edge of the core to the center. This showed that even N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> is not an ideal tracer for the chemistry of dense [[pre-stellar cores]], and concluded that H<sub>2</sub>D<sup>+</sup> may be the only good molecular probe of the innermost regions of pre-stellar cores.<ref>{{cite journal |title = N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> and C<sup>18</sup>O Depletion in a Cold Dark Cloud |last1 = Bergin |first1 = Edwin A. |last2 = Alves |first2 = João |last3 = Huard |first3 = Tracy |last4 = Lada |first4 = Charles J. |journal = [[The Astrophysical Journal Letters]] |issn = 1538-4357 |volume = 570 |issue = 2 |year = 2002 |pages = L101–L104 |doi = 10.1086/340950 |arxiv = astro-ph/0204016 |bibcode = 2002ApJ...570L.101B }}</ref>
== Laboratory detections == [[Image:N2H+ Energy Levels.png|200px|thumb|N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> Energy Levels]]
Although N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> is most often observed by astronomers because of its ease of detection, there have been some laboratory experiments that have observed it in a more controlled environment. The first laboratory spectrum of N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> was of the 1–0 rotational band in the ground vibrational level, the same microwave transition that astronomers had recently discovered in space.<ref>R. Saykally, T. Dixon, T. Anderson, P. Szanto, and R. Woods, ApJ, 205: L101 (1976)</ref>
Ten years later, Owrutsky et al. performed vibrational spectroscopy of N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> by observing the plasma created by a discharge of a mixture nitrogen, hydrogen, and argon gas using a color center laser. During the pulsed discharge, the poles were reversed on alternating pulses, so the ions were pulled back and forth through the discharge cell. This caused the absorption features of the ions, but not the neutral molecules, to be shifted back and forth in frequency space, so a lock-in amplifier could be used to observe the spectra of just the ions in the discharge. The lock-in combined with the velocity modulation gave >99.9% discrimination between ions and neutrals. The feed gas was optimized for N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> production, and transitions up to ''J'' = 41 were observed for both the fundamental N–H stretching band and the bending hot band.<ref>[http://scitation.aip.org/getabs/servlet/GetabsServlet?prog=normal&id=JCPSA6000084000002000605000001&idtype=cvips&gifs=yes J. Owrutsky, C. Gudeman, C. Martner, L. Tack, N. Rosenbaum, and R. Saykally, JCP, 84: 605 (1986)]</ref>
Later, Kabbadj et al. observed even more hot bands associated with the fundamental vibrational band using a difference frequency laser to observe a discharge of a mixture of nitrogen, hydrogen, and helium gases. They used velocity modulation in the same way that Owrutsky et al. had, in order to discriminate ions from neutrals. They combined this with a counterpropogating beam technique to aid in noise subtraction, and this greatly increased their sensitivity. They had enough sensitivity to observe OH<sup>+</sup>, H<sub>2</sub>O<sup>+</sup>, and H<sub>3</sub>O<sup>+</sup> that were formed from the minute O<sub>2</sub> and H<sub>2</sub>O impurities in their helium tank.<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022285284710162|doi=10.1006/jmsp.1994.1016|title=Infrared Spectroscopy of Highly Excited Vibrational Levels of Protonated Nitrogen, HN+2|journal=Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy|volume=163|issue=1|pages=180–205|year=1994|last1=Kabbadj|first1=Y|last2=Huet|first2=T.R|last3=Rehfuss|first3=B.D|last4=Gabrys|first4=C.M|last5=Oka|first5=T|bibcode=1994JMoSp.163..180K}}</ref>
[[Image:N2H+ Spectrum MHz.png|400px|left|thumb|Simulated N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> Rotational Spectrum]]
By fitting all observed bands, the rotational constants for N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> were determined to be ''B''<sub>''e''</sub> = 1.561928 cm<sup>−1</sup> and ''D''<sub>''e''</sub> = {{val|2.746e-6|u=cm<sup>−1</sup>}}, which are the only constants needed to determine the rotational spectrum of this linear molecule in the ground vibrational state, with the exception of determining hyperfine splitting. Given the [[selection rule]] Δ''J'' = ±1, the calculated rotational energy levels, along with their percent population at 30 [[kelvin]]s, can be plotted. The frequencies of the peaks predicted by this method differ from those observed in the laboratory by at most 700 kHz.
{{clear}}
== Chemistry == N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> is found mostly in dense molecular clouds, where its presence is closely related to that of many other nitrogen-containing compounds.<ref name="Prasad&Huntress1980">[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1980ApJS...43....1P S. Prasad and W. Huntress, ApJS, 43: 1-35 (1980)]</ref> It is particularly closely tied to the chemistry of N<sub>2</sub>, which is more difficult to detect (since it lacks a dipole moment). This is why N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> is commonly used to indirectly determine the abundance of N<sub>2</sub> in molecular clouds.
The rates of the dominant formation and destruction reactions can be determined from known rate constants and fractional abundances (relative to H<sub>2</sub>) in a typical dense molecular cloud.<ref>[http://aas.aanda.org/index.php?option=article&access=standard&Itemid=129&url=/articles/aas/abs/1997/01/ds1168/ds1168.html T. Millar, P. Farquhar, and K. Willacy, A\&A Supp, 121: 139 (1997)]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The calculated rates here were for early time (316,000 years) and a temperature of 20 kelvins, which are typical conditions for a relatively young molecular cloud.
:{|class=wikitable |+Production of diazenylium |- !Reaction ![[Rate constant]] !Rate/[H<sub>2</sub>]<sup>2</sup> !Relative rate |- |H<sub>2</sub> + {{chem|N|2|+}} → N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> + H |{{val|2.0e-9}} || {{val|1.7e-23}} || 1.0 |- |{{chem|H|3|+}} + N<sub>2</sub> → N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> + H<sub>2</sub> |{{val|1.8e-9}} || {{val|1.5e-22}} || 9.1 |}
:{|class=wikitable |+Destruction of diazenylium |- !Reaction ![[Rate constant]] !Rate/[H<sub>2</sub>]<sup>2</sup> !Relative rate |- | N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> + O → N<sub>2</sub> + OH<sup>+</sup> | {{val|1.4e-10}} || {{val|1.6e-23}} || 1.0 |- | N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> + CO → N<sub>2</sub> + HCO<sup>+</sup> | {{val|1.4e-10}} || {{val|5.0e-23}} || 3.2 |- | N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> + e<sup>–</sup> → N<sub>2</sub> + H | {{val|2.0e-6}} || {{val|4.4e-23}} || 2.8 |- | N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> + e<sup>–</sup> → NHN | {{val|2.6e-6}} || {{val|5.7e-23}} || 3.7 |}
There are dozens more reactions possible, but these are the only ones that are fast enough to affect the abundance of N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> in dense molecular clouds. Diazenylium thus plays a critical role in the chemistry of many nitrogen-containing molecules.<ref name="Prasad&Huntress1980"/> Although the actual electron density in so-called "dense clouds" is quite low, the destruction of N<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> is governed mostly by [[dissociative recombination]].
